title: It is apparent that Russia has a meaningful supply of the nerve agent Novichok. Is it a reasonable assumption that the United States has a supply of a counterpart super-secret poison? - Quora

response.answer_text: The United States is the only country in the world that still officially stockpiles hundreds of tons of military poisons. For example, Blue Grass Army Depot in Kentucky holds about 500 tons of various nerve agents. They are slated for destruction, but, for now, they are still there. Nobody needs “a meaningful supply” of Novichok to kill a single person. Allegedly, a single drop can be used to kill a platoon, as long as they get into contact with it. That amount of Novichok can be relatively easily produced in a lab. Novichok hasn’t been “super-secret” since the 1990s. Its secrets were provided to the West, and the Western labs had more than enough time to study it and even enhance it, if necessary. If I remember correctly, at one point, even a lab in Iran synthesized a tiny amount of Novichok to try the available formula.
